awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Virtual Reality technology for teacher-driven development of classroom-based  assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop technology to enable a gamified approach to the world of virtual reality (VR).  Current educational VR programs are focused on providing an experience through 360 degree videos or simple interactions allowing students to explore a virtual world. The advancement of the technology under development is the connection between student-centered experiential learning and an easy-access, teacher-driven assessment management system. By lowering the threshold of programming experience required to create and use VR technology in the classroom, teachers will be able to fine-tune VR resources to meet the student curricular needs. This will allow VR to seamlessly integrate into classrooms on a large scale.

This I-Corps project aims to evaluate the commercialization potential of technology using a multi-platform (VR, PC, Mac) gamification tool for student assessment. Teachers will be able to create assessments via an easy-to-use web interface that are then automatically placed inside the game portal for students to complete. After completing the assignment or quiz, a student will be rewarded with a short gameplay session where s/he can advance based on the performance during the assessment portion of the game. Teachers will be able to use the web interface to track student progress and results. The novel assessments created can be shared with other teachers to create a library of assessments, so that teachers can develop a new course efficiently.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We conducted over 100 interviews during the past year. Findings confirmed that early implementing schools are also facing challenges related to the usability difficulties, and ineffective classroom integration. But both of these issues are derived from limitations from current VR platforms and limited access to content aligned to national standards. Schools with no VR experience could not even understand the potential of the application. In fact with out havening an immersion experience in VR there is no way for potential customers to embrace the product solution. Teachers in VR schools identified that students that struggle with sustained attention during traditional instruction, showed a dramatic increase in their ability to say on topic when providing supplemental VR experiences. These students retained their heightened ability to focus beyond the VR experience through an increase in intrinsic motivation. As for “Learner differences”, teachers in our sample identified this as a selective advantage. These teachers described how VR experiences provided great value across all learners, and that building a VR component into a lesson was considered best practices for differentiation of instruction. Through this project we learned that assessment and classroom management are not a major concern for upper administration in secondary schools. The major "shark bite" problem that they face is teacher shortage but our technology does not address this issue. VR does have the capacity to address this problem but not in the form we have proposed here. Additional areas for consideration include: distance education, experiential learning, virtual field trips, VR instructional delivery and workforce development. We will continue our efforts to develop VR technology to address this new problem.
